div.head: CHAPTER I
IN WHICH WE ARE INTRODUCED TO
div.p: WINNIE-THE-POOH AND SOME BEES,
div.head: AND THE STORIES BEGIN
div.p: Here is Edward Bear, coming downstairs now, bump, bump, bump, on the back of his head, behind Christopher Robin. It is, as far as he knows, the only way of coming downstairs, but sometimes he feels that there really is another way, if only he could stop bumping for a moment and think of it. And then he feels that perhaps there isn't. Anyhow, here he is at the bottom, and ready to be introduced to you. Winnie-the-Pooh.
When I first heard his name, I said, just as you are going to say,
said Christopher Robin.

quote.s: "He's Winnie-ther-Pooh. Don't you know what 'ther' means?"

div.p: I said quickly; and I hope you do too, because it is all the explanation you are going to get.
Sometimes Winnie-the-Pooh likes a game of some sort when he comes downstairs, and sometimes he likes to sit quietly in front of the fire and listen to a story. This evening----
said Christopher Robin.
I said.

quote.s: "Could you very sweetly tell Winnie-the-Pooh one?"
"What sort of stories does he like?"
"About himself. Because he's that sort of Bear."

div.p: I said.
So I tried.
Once upon a time, a very long time ago now, about last Friday, Winnie-the-Pooh lived in a forest all by himself under the name of Sanders.
asked Christopher Robin._

quote.s: "It means he had the name over the door in gold letters, and lived\nunder it."

div.p: said Christopher Robin._
said a growly voice._
said I._)

One day when he was out walking, he came to an open place in the middle of the forest, and in the middle of this place was a large oak-tree, and, from the top of the tree, there came a loud buzzing-noise.
Winnie-the-Pooh sat down at the foot of the tree, put his head between his paws and began to think.
First of all he said to himself:

quote.s:
"That buzzing-noise means something.
You don't get a buzzing-noise like that, just buzzing and buzzing,
without its meaning something. If there's a buzzing-noise, somebody's
making a buzzing-noise, and the only reason for making a buzzing-noise
that I know of is because you're a bee."

div.p: Then he thought another long time, and said:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he thought another long time and said
quote.s: "And the only reason for\nbeing a bee that I know of is making honey."

div.p: And then he got up, and said:

quote.s: "And the only reason for making honey is\nso as I can eat it."

div.p: So he began to climb the tree.
He climbed and he climbed and he climbed, and as he climbed he sang a little song to himself. It went like this:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he sang a little song to himself It went like this
quote.s:
"Isn't it funny
 How a bear likes honey?
 Buzz! Buzz! Buzz!
 I wonder why he does?"

div.p: Then he climbed a little further ... and a little further ... and then just a little further. By that time he had thought of another song.

quote.s:
"It's a very funny thought that, if Bears were Bees,
 They'd build their nests at the bottom of trees.
 And that being so (if the Bees were Bears),
 We shouldn't have to climb up all these stairs."

div.p: He was getting rather tired by this time, so that is why he sang a Complaining Song. He was nearly there now, and if he just stood on that branch ...
_Crack!_
said Pooh, as he dropped ten feet on the branch below him.
he said, as he bounced twenty feet on to the next branch.
he admitted, as he slithered very quickly through the next six branches.

quote.s: "it all comes of liking honey so much. Oh, help!"

div.p: He crawled out of the gorse-bush, brushed the prickles from his nose, and began to think again. And the first person he thought of was Christopher Robin.
said Christopher Robin in an awed voice, hardly daring to believe it._
_Christopher Robin said nothing, but his eyes got larger and larger, and his face got pinker and pinker._)
So Winnie-the-Pooh went round to his friend Christopher Robin, who lived behind a green door in another part of the forest.
he said.
said you.

quote.s: "I wonder if you've got such a thing as a balloon about you?"
"Yes, I just said to myself coming along: 'I wonder if Christopher Robin\nhas such a thing as a balloon about him?' I just said it to myself,\nthinking of balloons, and wondering."
"What do you want a balloon for?"

div.p: you said.
Winnie-the-Pooh looked round to see that nobody was listening, put his paw to his mouth, and said in a deep whisper:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: WinniethePooh looked round to see that nobody was listening put his paw to his mouth and said

quote.s: "But you don't get honey with balloons!"

div.p: said Pooh.

Well, it just happened that you had been to a party the day before at the house of your friend Piglet, and you had balloons at the party. You had had a big green balloon; and one of Rabbit's relations had had a big blue one, and had left it behind, being really too young to go to a party at all; and so you had brought the green one _and_ the blue one home with you.
you asked Pooh.
He put his head between his paws and thought very carefully.

quote.s:
"When you go after honey with a balloon, the
great thing is not to let the bees know you're coming. Now, if you have
a green balloon, they might think you were only part of the tree, and
not notice you, and, if you have a blue balloon, they might think you
were only part of the sky, and not notice you, and the question is:
Which is most likely?"
"Wouldn't they notice you underneath the balloon?"

div.p: you asked.
He thought for a moment and said:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: He thought for a moment and said
quote.s: "I shall try to look\nlike a small black cloud. That will deceive them."
"Then you had better have the blue balloon,"

div.p: you said; and so it was decided.

Well, you both went out with the blue balloon, and you took your gun with you, just in case, as you always did, and Winnie-the-Pooh went to a very muddy place that he knew of, and rolled and rolled until he was black all over; and then, when the balloon was blown up as big as big, and you and Pooh were both holding on to the string, you let go suddenly, and Pooh Bear floated gracefully up into the sky, and stayed there--level with the top of the tree and about twenty feet away from it.
you shouted.

quote.s: "You look like a Bear holding on to a balloon,"

div.p: you said.

quote.s: "--not like a small black cloud in a blue\nsky?"
"Ah, well, perhaps from up here it looks different. And, as I say, you\nnever can tell with bees."

div.p: There was no wind to blow him nearer to the tree, so there he stayed. He could see the honey, he could smell the honey, but he couldn't quite reach the honey.
After a little while he called down to you.
he said in a loud whisper.

quote.s: "I don't know. But something tells me that they're suspicious!"
"Perhaps they think that you're after their honey."
"It may be that. You never can tell with bees."

div.p: There was another little silence, and then he called down to you again.

quote.s: "Have you an umbrella in your house?"

"I wish you would bring it out here, and walk up and down with it, and
look up at me every now and then, and say 'Tut-tut, it looks like rain.'
I think, if you did that, it would help the deception which we are
practising on these bees."

div.p: Well, you laughed to yourself,
but you didn't say it aloud because you were so fond of him, and you went home for your umbrella.

quote.s: "I was beginning to get anxious. I have discovered\nthat the bees are now definitely Suspicious."

div.p: you said.

quote.s: "Yes, but wait a moment. We must be practical. The important bee to\ndeceive is the Queen Bee. Can you see which is the Queen Bee from down\nthere?"
"A pity. Well, now, if you walk up and down with your umbrella, saying,\n'Tut-tut, it looks like rain,' I shall do what I can by singing a little\nCloud Song, such as a cloud might sing.... Go!"

div.p: So, while you walked up and down and wondered if it would rain, Winnie-the-Pooh sang this song:

quote.s:
""How sweet to be a Cloud
 Floating in the Blue!"
 It makes him very proud
 To be a little cloud."

div.p: The bees were still buzzing as suspiciously as ever. Some of them, indeed, left their nests and flew all round the cloud as it began the second verse of this song, and one bee sat down on the nose of the cloud for a moment, and then got up again.
called out the cloud.

quote.s: "I have just been thinking, and I have come to a very important\ndecision. These are the wrong sort of bees."
"Quite the wrong sort. So I should think they would make the wrong sort\nof honey, shouldn't you?"
"Yes. So I think I shall come down."

div.p: asked you.
Winnie-the-Pooh hadn't thought about this. If he let go of the string, he would fall--_bump_--and he didn't like the idea of that. So he thought for a long time, and then he said:

quote.s: "Christopher Robin, you must shoot the balloon with your gun. Have you\ngot your gun?"
"But if I do that, it will spoil the\nballoon,"

div.p: you said.
said Pooh.
you asked.
you said, and you fired again, and this time you hit the balloon, and the air came slowly out, and Winnie-the-Pooh floated down to the ground.

But his arms were so stiff from holding on to the string of the balloon all that time that they stayed up straight in the air for more than a week, and whenever a fly came and settled on his nose he had to blow it off. And I think--but I am not sure--that _that_ is why he was always called Pooh.

quote.s: "Is that the end of the story?"

div.p: asked Christopher Robin.

quote.s: "That's the end of that one. There are others."
"And Piglet and Rabbit and all of you. Don't you remember?"
"I do remember, and then when I try to remember, I forget."
"That day when Pooh and Piglet tried to catch the Heffalump----"
"Pooh couldn't, because he hasn't any brain. Did I catch it?"

div.p: Christopher Robin nodded.

quote.s: "only Pooh doesn't very well, so that's why he\nlikes having it told to him again. Because then it's a real story and\nnot just a remembering."

div.p: I said.
Christopher Robin gave a deep sigh, picked his Bear up by the leg, and walked off to the door, trailing Pooh behind him. At the door he turned and said,

quote.s: "Coming to see me have my bath?"

div.p: I said.

quote.s: "I didn't hurt him when I shot him, did I?"

div.p: He nodded and went out, and in a moment I heard Winnie-the-Pooh--_bump, bump, bump_--going up the stairs behind him.
div.head: CHAPTER II
IN WHICH POOH GOES VISITING AND
GETS INTO A TIGHT PLACE
div.p: Edward Bear, known to his friends as Winnie-the-Pooh, or Pooh for short, was walking through the forest one day, humming proudly to himself. He had made up a little hum that very morning, as he was doing his Stoutness Exercises in front of the glass: _Tra-la-la, tra-la-la_, as he stretched up as high as he could go, and then _Tra-la-la, tra-la--oh, help!--la_, as he tried to reach his toes. After breakfast he had said it over and over to himself until he had learnt it off by heart, and now he was humming it right through, properly. It went like this:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he was humming it right through properly It went like this
quote.s:
"Tra-la-la, tra-la-la,
 Tra-la-la, tra-la-la,
 Rum-tum-tiddle-um-tum.
 Tiddle-iddle, tiddle-iddle,
 Tiddle-iddle, tiddle-iddle,
 Rum-tum-tum-tiddle-um."

div.p: Well, he was humming this hum to himself, and walking along gaily, wondering what everybody else was doing, and what it felt like, being somebody else, when suddenly he came to a sandy bank, and in the bank was a large hole.

quote.s: "and Company means Food and Listening-to-Me-Humming and such\nlike. Rum-tum-tum-tiddle-um."

div.p: So he bent down, put his head into the hole, and called out:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he bent down put his head into the hole and called out

div.p: There was a sudden scuffling noise from inside the hole, and then silence.

quote.s: "What I said was, 'Is anybody at home?'"

div.p: called out Pooh very loudly.

quote.s: "You needn't shout so loud. I heard\nyou quite well the first time."

div.p: Winnie-the-Pooh took his head out of the hole, and thought for a little, and he thought to himself,

quote.s: "There must be somebody there, because\nsomebody must have said 'Nobody.'"

div.p: So he put his head back in the hole, and said:
said Rabbit, in a different sort of voice this time.
said Pooh.
He took his head out of the hole, and had another think, and then he put it back, and said:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he put it back and said
quote.s: "Well, could you very kindly tell me where Rabbit is?"
"He has gone to see his friend Pooh Bear, who is a great friend of his."

div.p: said Bear, very much surprised.
said Rabbit, still more surprised.
said Pooh.
So Pooh pushed and pushed and pushed his way through the hole, and at last he got in.

quote.s: "Well, I wasn't sure. You know how it is in the Forest. One can't have\nanybody coming into one's house. One has to be careful. What about a\nmouthful of something?"

div.p: Pooh always liked a little something at eleven o'clock in the morning, and he was very glad to see Rabbit getting out the plates and mugs; and when Rabbit said,

quote.s: "Honey or condensed milk with your bread?"

div.p: he was so excited that he said,
and then, so as not to seem greedy, he added,

quote.s: "But don't bother about the bread, please."

div.p: And for a long time after that he said nothing ... until at last, humming to himself in a rather sticky voice, he got up, shook Rabbit lovingly by the paw, and said that he must be going on.
said Rabbit politely.

quote.s: "I could stay a little longer if it--if you----"

div.p: and he tried very hard to look in the direction of the larder.

quote.s: "Oh, well, then, I'll be going on. Good-bye."
"Well, good-bye, if you're sure you won't have any more."

div.p: asked Pooh quickly.
Rabbit took the covers off the dishes, and said,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Rabbit took the covers off the dishes and said

div.p: Now by this time Rabbit wanted to go for a walk too, and finding the front door full, he went out by the back door, and came round to Pooh, and looked at him.
he asked.

quote.s: "Just resting and thinking and humming to\nmyself."

div.p: Pooh Bear stretched out a paw, and Rabbit pulled and pulled and pulled....

quote.s: "Well, well, I shall go and fetch Christopher\nRobin."

div.p: Christopher Robin lived at the other end of the Forest, and when he came back with Rabbit, and saw the front half of Pooh, he said,
in such a loving voice that everybody felt quite hopeful again.

quote.s: "that\nRabbit might never be able to use his front door again. And I should\nhate that,"

div.p: he said.
said Rabbit.

quote.s: "Of course he'll use\nhis front door again."

div.p: said Rabbit.

quote.s: "If we can't pull you out, Pooh, we might push you back."

div.p: Rabbit scratched his whiskers thoughtfully, and pointed out that, when once Pooh was pushed back, he was back, and of course nobody was more glad to see Pooh than _he_ was, still there it was, some lived in trees and some lived underground, and----
said Pooh.

quote.s: "that having got so far, it seems a pity to\nwaste it."

div.p: Christopher Robin nodded.

quote.s: "We shall have to\nwait for you to get thin again."

div.p: asked Pooh anxiously.

quote.s: "But I can't stay here for a week!"
"You can stay here all right, silly old Bear. It's getting you out\nwhich is so difficult."

"And I say, old fellow, you're taking up a good deal of room
in my house--do you mind if I use your back legs as a towel-horse?
Because, I mean, there they are--doing nothing--and it would be very
convenient just to hang the towels on them."
"because of getting thin\nquicker. But we will read to you."

div.p: Bear began to sigh, and then found he couldn't because he was so tightly stuck; and a tear rolled down his eye, as he said:

quote.s: "Then would you read a Sustaining Book, such as would help and comfort a\nWedged Bear in Great Tightness?"

div.p: So for a week Christopher Robin read that sort of book at the North end of Pooh, and Rabbit hung his washing on the South end ... and in between Bear felt himself getting slenderer and slenderer. And at the end of the week Christopher Robin said,
So he took hold of Pooh's front paws and Rabbit took hold of Christopher Robin, and all Rabbit's friends and relations took hold of Rabbit, and they all pulled together....
And for a long time Pooh only said
And then, all of a sudden, he said
just as if a cork were coming out of a bottle.
And Christopher Robin and Rabbit and all Rabbit's friends and relations went head-over-heels backwards ... and on the top of them came Winnie-the-Pooh--free!
So, with a nod of thanks to his friends, he went on with his walk through the forest, humming proudly to himself. But, Christopher Robin looked after him lovingly, and said to himself,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Christopher Robin looked after him lovingly and said to himself

div.head: CHAPTER III
IN WHICH POOH AND PIGLET GO HUNTING
AND NEARLY CATCH A WOOZLE
div.p: The Piglet lived in a very grand house in the middle of a beech-tree, and the beech-tree was in the middle of the forest, and the Piglet lived in the middle of the house. Next to his house was a piece of broken board which had: "TRESPASSERS W" on it. When Christopher Robin asked the Piglet what it meant, he said it was his grandfather's name, and had been in the family for a long time, Christopher Robin said you _couldn't_ be called Trespassers W, and Piglet said yes, you could, because his grandfather was, and it was short for Trespassers Will, which was short for Trespassers William. And his grandfather had had two names in case he lost one--Trespassers after an uncle, and William after Trespassers.
said Christopher Robin carelessly.

quote.s: "Well, there you are, that proves it,"

div.p: said Piglet.

One fine winter's day when Piglet was brushing away the snow in front of his house, he happened to look up, and there was Winnie-the-Pooh. Pooh was walking round and round in a circle, thinking of something else, and when Piglet called to him, he just went on walking.
said Pooh.
said Winnie-the-Pooh very mysteriously.
said Piglet, coming closer.

quote.s: "That's just what I ask myself. I ask myself, What?"
"Oh, Pooh! Do you think it's a--a--a Woozle?"
"Sometimes it is, and sometimes it isn't. You\nnever can tell with paw-marks."

div.p: With these few words he went on tracking, and Piglet, after watching him for a minute or two, ran after him. Winnie-the-Pooh had come to a sudden stop, and was bending over the tracks in a puzzled sort of way.
asked Piglet.

quote.s:
"but there seem to be
two animals now. This--whatever-it-was--has been joined by
another--whatever-it-is--and the two of them are now proceeding
in company. Would you mind coming with me, Piglet, in case they
turn out to be Hostile Animals?"

div.p: Piglet scratched his ear in a nice sort of way, and said that he had nothing to do until Friday, and would be delighted to come, in case it really _was_ a Woozle.

quote.s: "You mean, in case it really is two Woozles,"

div.p: said Winnie-the-Pooh, and Piglet said that anyhow he had nothing to do until Friday. So off they went together.

There was a small spinney of larch trees just here, and it seemed as if the two Woozles, if that is what they were, had been going round this spinney; so round this spinney went Pooh and Piglet after them; Piglet passing the time by telling Pooh what his Grandfather Trespassers W had done to Remove Stiffness after Tracking, and how his Grandfather Trespassers W had suffered in his later years from Shortness of Breath, and other matters of interest, and Pooh wondering what a Grandfather was like, and if perhaps this was Two Grandfathers they were after now, and, if so, whether he would be allowed to take one home and keep it, and what Christopher Robin would say. And still the tracks went on in front of them....

Suddenly Winnie-the-Pooh stopped, and pointed excitedly in front of him. said Piglet, with a jump. And then, to show that he hadn't been frightened, he jumped up and down once or twice more in an exercising sort of way.

quote.s: "A third animal has joined the other two!"
"Do you think it is another Woozle?"
"because it makes different marks. It is either Two\nWoozles and one, as it might be, Wizzle, or Two, as it might be, Wizzles\nand one, if so it is, Woozle. Let us continue to follow them."

div.p: So they went on, feeling just a little anxious now, in case the three animals in front of them were of Hostile Intent. And Piglet wished very much that his Grandfather T. W. were there, instead of elsewhere, and Pooh thought how nice it would be if they met Christopher Robin suddenly but quite accidentally, and only because he liked Christopher Robin so much. And then, all of a sudden, Winnie-the-Pooh stopped again, and licked the tip of his nose in a cooling manner, for he was feeling more hot and anxious than ever in his life before. _There were four animals in front of them!_

quote.s: "Do you see, Piglet? Look at their tracks! Three, as it were, Woozles,\nand one, as it was, Wizzle. Another Woozle has joined them!"

div.p: And so it seemed to be. There were the tracks; crossing over each other here, getting muddled up with each other there; but, quite plainly every now and then, the tracks of four sets of paws.

quote.s:
"I think that I have
just remembered something. I have just remembered something that I
forgot to do yesterday and shan't be able to do to-morrow. So I suppose
I really ought to go back and do it now."
"We'll do it this afternoon, and I'll come with you,"

div.p: said Pooh.

quote.s: "It's a very particular morning thing, that has to be done in\nthe morning, and, if possible, between the hours of----What would you\nsay the time was?"

div.p: said Winnie-the-Pooh, looking at the sun.

quote.s: "Between, as I was saying, the hours of twelve and twelve five. So,\nreally, dear old Pooh, if you'll excuse me----What's that?"

div.p: Pooh looked up at the sky, and then, as he heard the whistle again, he looked up into the branches of a big oak-tree, and then he saw a friend of his.
he said.
and he trotted off home as quickly as he could, very glad to be Out of All Danger again.
Christopher Robin came slowly down his tree.

quote.s:
"what were you doing? First you went round
the spinney twice by yourself, and then Piglet ran after you and you
went round again together, and then you were just going round a fourth
time----"

div.p: said Winnie-the-Pooh.

quote.s: "and I am a Bear of No Brain\nat All."
"You're the Best Bear in All the World,"

div.p: said Christopher Robin soothingly.
said Pooh hopefully. And then he brightened up suddenly.
So he went home for it.
div.head: CHAPTER IV
IN WHICH EEYORE LOSES A TAIL
AND POOH FINDS ONE
div.p: The Old Grey Donkey, Eeyore, stood by himself in a thistly corner of the forest, his front feet well apart, his head on one side, and thought about things. Sometimes he thought sadly to himself,
and sometimes he thought,
--and sometimes he didn't quite know what he _was_ thinking about. So when Winnie-the-Pooh came stumping along, Eeyore was very glad to be able to stop thinking for a little, in order to say

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Eeyore was very glad to be able to stop thinking for a little in order to say

div.p: in a gloomy manner to him.
said Winnie-the-Pooh.
Eeyore shook his head from side to side.

quote.s: "I don't seem to have felt at all how for a\nlong time."
"I'm sorry about that. Let's have a look at\nyou."

div.p: So Eeyore stood there, gazing sadly at the ground, and Winnie-the-Pooh walked all round him once.
he said in surprise.
said Eeyore.

quote.s: "Well, either a tail is there or it isn't there. You can't make a\nmistake about it. And yours isn't there!"

div.p: said Eeyore, and he turned slowly round to the place where his tail had been a little while ago, and then, finding that he couldn't catch it up, he turned round the other way, until he came back to where he was at first, and then he put his head down and looked between his front legs, and at last he said, with a long, sad sigh,
said Pooh.
said Winnie-the-Pooh.
said Eeyore.
he added, after a long silence.
Pooh felt that he ought to say something helpful about it, but didn't quite know what. So he decided to do something helpful instead.

quote.s: "I, Winnie-the-Pooh, will find your tail for\nyou."

div.p: answered Eeyore.
said he. he said.
So Winnie-the-Pooh went off to find Eeyore's tail.

It was a fine spring morning in the forest as he started out. Little soft clouds played happily in a blue sky, skipping from time to time in front of the sun as if they had come to put it out, and then sliding away suddenly so that the next might have his turn. Through them and between them the sun shone bravely; and a copse which had worn its firs all the year round seemed old and dowdy now beside the new green lace which the beeches had put on so prettily. Through copse and spinney marched Bear; down open slopes of gorse and heather, over rocky beds of streams, up steep banks of sandstone into the heather again; and so at last, tired and hungry, to the Hundred Acre Wood. For it was in the Hundred Acre Wood that Owl lived.
he said.

Owl lived at The Chestnuts, an old-world residence of great charm, which was grander than anybody else's, or seemed so to Bear, because it had both a knocker _and_ a bell-pull. Underneath the knocker there was a notice which said:
PLES RING IF AN RNSER IS REQIRD.
Underneath the bell-pull there was a notice which said:
PLEZ CNOKE IF AN RNSR IS NOT REQID.

These notices had been written by Christopher Robin, who was the only one in the forest who could spell; for Owl, wise though he was in many ways, able to read and write and spell his own name WOL, yet somehow went all to pieces over delicate words like MEASLES and BUTTEREDTOAST.

Winnie-the-Pooh read the two notices very carefully, first from left to right, and afterwards, in case he had missed some of it, from right to left. Then, to make quite sure, he knocked and pulled the knocker, and he pulled and knocked the bell-rope, and he called out in a very loud voice,

quote.s: "Owl! I require an answer! It's Bear speaking."

div.p: And the door opened, and Owl looked out.

quote.s: "because Eeyore, who is a friend of mine,\nhas lost his tail. And he's Moping about it. So could you very kindly\ntell me how to find it for him?"
"the customary procedure in such cases is as follows."
"For I am a Bear of\nVery Little Brain, and long words Bother me."
"As long as it means that, I don't mind,"

div.p: said Pooh humbly.

quote.s: "The thing to do is as follows. First, Issue a Reward. Then----"
"What do we do to\nthis--what you were saying? You sneezed just as you were going to tell\nme."
"Excuse me, Pooh, I didn't. You can't sneeze without knowing it."
"Well, you can't know it without something having been sneezed."
"What I said was, 'First Issue a Reward'."

div.p: said Pooh sadly.

quote.s: "We write a notice to say that we will\ngive a large something to anybody who finds Eeyore's tail."

div.p: said Pooh, nodding his head.

quote.s: "just a mouthful of\ncondensed milk or whatnot, with perhaps a lick of honey----"
"we write out this notice, and we put it up all\nover the forest."

div.p: And he gave a deep sigh, and tried very hard to listen to what Owl was saying.
But Owl went on and on, using longer and longer words, until at last he came back to where he started, and he explained that the person to write out this notice was Christopher Robin.

quote.s: "It was he who wrote the ones on my front door for me. Did you see them,\nPooh?"

div.p: For some time now Pooh had been saying "Yes" and "No" in turn, with his eyes shut, to all that Owl was saying, and having said, "Yes, yes," last time, he said
now, without really knowing what Owl was talking about.
said Owl.
Pooh nodded.

quote.s: "but I can't think what. Where\ndid you get it?"

"I just came across it in the Forest. It was hanging over a bush, and I
thought at first somebody lived there, so I rang it, and nothing
happened, and then I rang it again very loudly, and it came off in my
hand, and as nobody seemed to want it, I took it home, and----"
"you made a mistake. Somebody did want it."
"Eeyore. My dear friend Eeyore. He was--he was fond of it."

div.p: said Winnie-the-Pooh sadly.

So with these words he unhooked it, and carried it back to Eeyore; and when Christopher Robin had nailed it on in its right place again, Eeyore frisked about the forest, waving his tail so happily that Winnie-the-Pooh came over all funny, and had to hurry home for a little snack of something to sustain him. And, wiping his mouth half an hour afterwards, he sang to himself proudly:

quote.s:
"Who found the Tail?
 "I," said Pooh,
 "At a quarter to two
 (Only it was quarter to eleven really),
 I found the Tail!""

div.head: CHAPTER V
IN WHICH PIGLET MEETS A HEFFALUMP
div.p: One day, when Christopher Robin and Winnie-the-Pooh and Piglet were all talking together, Christopher Robin finished the mouthful he was eating and said carelessly:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Christopher Robin finished the mouthful he was eating and said

div.p: asked Piglet.
said Piglet.
said Pooh, wondering what a Heffalump was like.
said Christopher Robin carelessly.
said Piglet.
said Pooh.

Then they all talked about something else, until it was time for Pooh and Piglet to go home together. At first as they stumped along the path which edged the Hundred Acre Wood, they didn't say much to each other; but when they came to the stream and had helped each other across the stepping stones, and were able to walk side by side again over the heather, they began to talk in a friendly way about this and that, and Piglet said,

quote.s: "If you see what I mean, Pooh,"

div.p: and Pooh said,
and Piglet said,

quote.s: "But, on the other hand,\nPooh, we must remember,"

div.p: and Pooh said,

quote.s: "Quite true, Piglet, although I\nhad forgotten it for the moment."

div.p: And then, just as they came to the Six Pine Trees, Pooh looked round to see that nobody else was listening, and said in a very solemn voice:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Pooh looked round to see that nobody else was listening and said

quote.s: "I have decided to catch a Heffalump."

div.p: Pooh nodded his head several times as he said this, and waited for Piglet to say "How?" or "Pooh, you couldn't!" or something helpful of that sort, but Piglet said nothing. The fact was Piglet was wishing that _he_ had thought about it first.

quote.s: "by means of\na trap. And it must be a Cunning Trap, so you will have to help me,\nPiglet."

div.p: And then he said,
and Pooh said,
And then they sat down together to think it out.
Pooh's first idea was that they should dig a Very Deep Pit, and then the Heffalump would come along and fall into the Pit, and----
said Piglet.
said Pooh.

Pooh rubbed his nose with his paw, and said that the Heffalump might be walking along, humming a little song, and looking up at the sky, wondering if it would rain, and so he wouldn't see the Very Deep Pit until he was half-way down, when it would be too late.
Piglet said that this was a very good Trap, but supposing it were raining already?

Pooh rubbed his nose again, and said that he hadn't thought of that. And then he brightened up, and said that, if it were raining already, the Heffalump would be looking at the sky wondering if it would _clear up_, and so he wouldn't see the Very Deep Pit until he was half-way down.... When it would be too late.
Piglet said that, now that this point had been explained, he thought it was a Cunning Trap.

Pooh was very proud when he heard this, and he felt that the Heffalump was as good as caught already, but there was just one other thing which had to be thought about, and it was this. _Where should they dig the Very Deep Pit?_
Piglet said that the best place would be somewhere where a Heffalump was, just before he fell into it, only about a foot farther on.

quote.s: "But then he would see us digging it,"

div.p: said Pooh.

quote.s: "Not if he was looking at the sky."

div.p: He thought for a long time and then added sadly,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: He thought for a long time and then added
quote.s: "It isn't as easy as I thought. I\nsuppose that's why Heffalumps hardly ever get caught."

div.p: said Piglet.
They sighed and got up; and when they had taken a few gorse prickles out of themselves they sat down again; and all the time Pooh was saying to himself,

quote.s: "If only I could think of something!"

div.p: For he felt sure that a Very Clever Brain could catch a Heffalump if only he knew the right way to go about it.

quote.s: "you wanted to catch me, how would you\ndo it?"
"I should do it like this. I should make a Trap,\nand I should put a Jar of Honey in the Trap, and you would smell it, and\nyou would go in after it, and----"

"only very carefully
so as not to hurt myself, and I would get to the Jar of Honey, and I
should lick round the edges first of all, pretending that there wasn't
any more, you know, and then I should walk away and think about it a
little, and then I should come back and start licking in the middle of
the jar, and then----"

"Yes, well never mind about that. There you would be, and there I should
catch you. Now the first thing to think of is, What do Heffalumps like?
I should think acorns, shouldn't you? We'll get a lot of----I say, wake
up, Pooh!"

div.p: Pooh, who had gone into a happy dream, woke up with a start, and said that Honey was a much more trappy thing than Haycorns. Piglet didn't think so; and they were just going to argue about it, when Piglet remembered that, if they put acorns in the Trap, _he_ would have to find the acorns, but if they put honey, then Pooh would have to give up some of his own honey, so he said,
just as Pooh remembered it too, and was going to say, "All right, haycorns.

quote.s: "I'll dig the pit, while you go and get the honey."
"I remember my uncle saying once that he had seen cheese just\nthis colour."

div.p: So he put his tongue in, and took a large lick.

quote.s: "I\nwas right. It is honey, right the way down."

div.p: Having made certain of this, he took the jar back to Piglet, and Piglet looked up from the bottom of his Very Deep Pit, and said,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Piglet looked up from the bottom of his Very Deep Pit and said

div.p: and Pooh said,

quote.s: "Yes, but it isn't quite a full jar,"

div.p: and he threw it down to Piglet, and Piglet said,

quote.s: "No, it isn't! Is that all you've got left?"

div.p: and Pooh said
Because it was. So Piglet put the jar at the bottom of the Pit, and climbed out, and they went off home together.

quote.s: "And we meet at six o'clock to-morrow morning by the Pine Trees,\nand see how many Heffalumps we've got in our Trap."
"Six o'clock, Piglet. And have you got any string?"
"Oh! ... I think Heffalumps come if you whistle."
"Some do and some don't. You never can tell with Heffalumps. Well, good\nnight!"

div.p: And off Piglet trotted to his house TRESPASSERS W, while Pooh made his preparations for bed.

Some hours later, just as the night was beginning to steal away, Pooh woke up suddenly with a sinking feeling. He had had that sinking feeling before, and he knew what it meant. _He was hungry._ So he went to the larder, and he stood on a chair and reached up to the top shelf, and found--nothing.

quote.s: "I know I had a jar of honey there. A full\njar, full of honey right up to the top, and it had HUNNY written on it,\nso that I should know it was honey. That's very funny."

div.p: And then he began to wander up and down, wondering where it was and murmuring a murmur to himself. Like this:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he began to wander up and down wondering where it was and murmuring a murmur to himself
quote.s:
"It's very, very funny,
 'Cos I know I had some honey;
 'Cos it had a label on,
 Saying HUNNY.
 A goloptious full-up pot too,
 And I don't know where it's got to,
 No, I don't know where it's gone--
 Well, it's funny."

div.p: He had murmured this to himself three times in a singing sort of way, when suddenly he remembered. He had put it into the Cunning Trap to catch the Heffalump.

quote.s: "It all comes of trying to be kind to Heffalumps."

div.p: And he got back into bed.

But he couldn't sleep. The more he tried to sleep, the more he couldn't. He tried Counting Sheep, which is sometimes a good way of getting to sleep, and, as that was no good, he tried counting Heffalumps. And that was worse. Because every Heffalump that he counted was making straight for a pot of Pooh's honey, _and eating it all_. For some minutes he lay there miserably, but when the five hundred and eighty-seventh Heffalump was licking its jaws, and saying to itself,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Heffalump was licking its jaws and saying to itself
quote.s: "Very good honey this, I\ndon't know when I've tasted better,"

div.p: Pooh could bear it no longer. He jumped out of bed, he ran out of the house, and he ran straight to the Six Pine Trees.

The Sun was still in bed, but there was a lightness in the sky over the Hundred Acre Wood which seemed to show that it was waking up and would soon be kicking off the clothes. In the half-light the Pine Trees looked cold and lonely, and the Very Deep Pit seemed deeper than it was, and Pooh's jar of honey at the bottom was something mysterious, a shape and no more. But as he got nearer to it his nose told him that it was indeed honey, and his tongue came out and began to polish up his mouth, ready for it.
And then he thought a little and said,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he thought a little and said

div.p: Indeed, he had eaten most of it. But there was a little left at the very bottom of the jar, and he pushed his head right in, and began to lick....
By and by Piglet woke up. As soon as he woke he said to himself,
Then he said bravely,
But he didn't feel very brave, for the word which was really jiggeting about in his brain was "Heffalumps.
What was a Heffalump like?
Was it Fierce?
_Did_ it come when you whistled? And _how_ did it come?
Was it Fond of Pigs at all?
If it was Fond of Pigs, did it make any difference _what sort of Pig_?
Supposing it was Fierce with Pigs, would it make any difference _if the Pig had a grandfather called TRESPASSERS WILLIAM_?
He didn't know the answer to any of these questions ... and he was going to see his first Heffalump in about an hour from now!

Of course Pooh would be with him, and it was much more Friendly with two. But suppose Heffalumps were Very Fierce with Pigs _and_ Bears? Wouldn't it be better to pretend that he had a headache, and couldn't go up to the Six Pine Trees this morning? But then suppose that it was a very fine day, and there was no Heffalump in the trap, here he would be, in bed all the morning, simply wasting his time for nothing. What should he do?

And then he had a Clever Idea. He would go up very quietly to the Six Pine Trees now, peep very cautiously into the Trap, and see if there _was_ a Heffalump there. And if there was, he would go back to bed, and if there wasn't, he wouldn't.

So off he went. At first he thought that there wouldn't be a Heffalump in the Trap, and then he thought that there would, and as he got nearer he was _sure_ that there would, because he could hear it heffalumping about it like anything.
said Piglet to himself. And he wanted to run away. But somehow, having got so near, he felt that he must just see what a Heffalump was like. So he crept to the side of the Trap and looked in....
And all the time Winnie-the-Pooh had been trying to get the honey-jar off his head. The more he shook it, the more tightly it stuck.

And he tried bumping it against things, but as he couldn't see what he was bumping it against, it didn't help him; and he tried to climb out of the Trap, but as he could see nothing but jar, and not much of that, he couldn't find his way. So at last he lifted up his head, jar and all, and made a loud, roaring noise of Sadness and Despair ... and it was at that moment that Piglet looked down.
and he scampered off as hard as he could, still crying out,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he he could still crying out
quote.s: "Help, help, a\nHerrible Hoffalump! Hoff, Hoff, a Hellible Horralump! Holl, Holl, a\nHoffable Hellerump!"

div.p: And he didn't stop crying and scampering until he got to Christopher Robin's house.
said Christopher Robin, who was just getting up.
said Piglet, waving his paw.

quote.s: "Like--like----It had the biggest head you ever saw, Christopher Robin.\nA great enormous thing, like--like nothing. A huge big--well, like a--I\ndon't know--like an enormous big nothing. Like a jar."
"I shall go and\nlook at it. Come on."

div.p: Piglet wasn't afraid if he had Christopher Robin with him, so off they went....
said Piglet anxiously, as they got near.
said Christopher Robin.
It was Pooh bumping his head against a tree-root he had found.
And he held on tight to Christopher Robin's hand.

Suddenly Christopher Robin began to laugh ... and he laughed ... and he laughed ... and he laughed. And while he was still laughing--_Crash_ went the Heffalump's head against the tree-root, Smash went the jar, and out came Pooh's head again....

Then Piglet saw what a Foolish Piglet he had been, and he was so ashamed of himself that he ran straight off home and went to bed with a headache. But Christopher Robin and Pooh went home to breakfast together.
said Pooh.
div.head: CHAPTER VI
IN WHICH EEYORE HAS A BIRTHDAY
AND GETS TWO PRESENTS
div.p: Eeyore, the old grey Donkey, stood by the side of the stream, and looked at himself in the water.

quote.s: "No better from this side. But nobody minds.\nNobody cares. Pathetic, that's what it is."

div.p: There was a crackling noise in the bracken behind him, and out came Pooh.
said Pooh.
said Eeyore gloomily.
said he.

quote.s: "Nothing, Pooh Bear, nothing. We can't all, and some of us don't. That's\nall there is to it."

div.p: said Pooh, rubbing his nose.

quote.s: "Gaiety. Song-and-dance. Here we go round the mulberry bush."

div.p: said Pooh. He thought for a long time, and then asked,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: He thought for a long time and then asked

div.p: went on Eeyore gloomily.

quote.s: "I'm not complaining, but There It Is."

div.p: Pooh sat down on a large stone, and tried to think this out. It sounded to him like a riddle, and he was never much good at riddles, being a Bear of Very Little Brain. So he sang _Cottleston Pie_ instead:

quote.s:
"Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie,
 A fly can't bird, but a bird can fly.
 Ask me a riddle and I reply:
 "Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie.""

div.p: That was the first verse. When he had finished it, Eeyore didn't actually say that he didn't like it, so Pooh very kindly sang the second verse to him:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Pooh very kindly sang the second verse to him
quote.s:
"Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie,
 A fish can't whistle and neither can I.
 Ask me a riddle and I reply:
 "Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie.""

div.p: Eeyore still said nothing at all, so Pooh hummed the third verse quietly to himself:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Pooh hummed the third verse quietly to himself
quote.s:
"Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie,
 Why does a chicken, I don't know why.
 Ask me a riddle and I reply:
 "Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie.""
"Sing. Umty-tiddly, umty-too. Here we go\ngathering Nuts and May. Enjoy yourself."

div.p: said Pooh.
said Eeyore.

quote.s: "Sad? Why should I be sad? It's my birthday. The happiest day of the\nyear."

div.p: said Pooh in great surprise.

quote.s: "Of course it is. Can't you see? Look at all the presents I have had."

div.p: He waved a foot from side to side.

quote.s: "Look at the birthday cake. Candles\nand pink sugar."

div.p: Pooh looked--first to the right and then to the left.
said Pooh.
said Eeyore.
Pooh scratched his head, being a little puzzled by all this.
he asked.

quote.s: "Oh! Well, Many happy returns of the day, Eeyore."
"And many happy returns to you, Pooh Bear."
"Well, why not? You don't always want to be miserable on my birthday, do\nyou?"

div.p: said Pooh.

quote.s:
"being miserable
myself, what with no presents and no cake and no candles, and no proper
notice taken of me at all, but if everybody else is going to be
miserable too----"

div.p: This was too much for Pooh.

he called to Eeyore, as he turned and hurried back home as quick as he could; for he felt that he must get poor Eeyore a present of _some_ sort at once, and he could always think of a proper one afterwards.
Outside his house he found Piglet, jumping up and down trying to reach the knocker.
he said.
said Piglet.
said Pooh kindly. So he reached up and knocked at the door.

quote.s:
"and poor Eeyore is in
a Very Sad Condition, because it's his birthday, and nobody has taken
any notice of it, and he's very Gloomy--you know what Eeyore is--and
there he was, and----What a long time whoever lives here is answering
this door."

div.p: And he knocked again.
said Pooh.
So in they went. The first thing Pooh did was to go to the cupboard to see if he had quite a small jar of honey left; and he had, so he took it down.

quote.s: "as a present. What are you\ngoing to give?"
"That would not be a good plan."
"All right, then, I'll give him a balloon. I've got one left from my\nparty. I'll go and get it now, shall I?"
"That, Piglet, is a very good idea. It is just what Eeyore wants to\ncheer him up. Nobody can be uncheered with a balloon."

div.p: So off Piglet trotted; and in the other direction went Pooh, with his jar of honey.

It was a warm day, and he had a long way to go. He hadn't gone more than half-way when a sort of funny feeling began to creep all over him. It began at the tip of his nose and trickled all through him and out at the soles of his feet. It was just as if somebody inside him were saying, Now then, Pooh, time for a little something.

quote.s: "I didn't know it was as late as that."

div.p: So he sat down and took the top off his jar of honey.

quote.s: "where was I going? Ah, yes, Eeyore."

div.p: He got up slowly.
And then, suddenly, he remembered. He had eaten Eeyore's birthday present!

quote.s: "What shall I do? I must give him\nsomething."
"Well, it's a very nice pot, even if there's no honey in it, and if I\nwashed it clean, and got somebody to write 'A Happy Birthday' on it,\nEeyore could keep things in it, which might be Useful."

div.p: For a little while he couldn't think of anything. Then he thought: So, as he was just passing the Hundred Acre Wood, he went inside to call on Owl, who lived there.
he said.
said Owl.
said Pooh.

quote.s: "I'm giving him a Useful Pot to Keep Things In, and I wanted to ask\nyou----"

div.p: said Owl, taking it out of Pooh's paw.

quote.s: "Yes, and I wanted to ask you----"
"Somebody has been keeping honey in it,"

div.p: said Owl.
You can keep _anything_ in it," said Pooh earnestly. "It's Very Useful like that. And I wanted to ask you----

quote.s: "You ought to write 'A Happy Birthday' on it."
"Because my spelling\nis Wobbly. It's good spelling but it Wobbles, and the letters get in the\nwrong places. Would you write 'A Happy Birthday' on it for me?"
"Couldn't I give\nit too? From both of us?"
"That would not be a good plan. Now I'll just wash it\nfirst, and then you can write on it."

div.p: Well, he washed the pot out, and dried it, while Owl licked the end of his pencil, and wondered how to spell "birthday.

quote.s: "There's a notice\nabout knocking and ringing outside my door, which Christopher Robin\nwrote. Could you read it?"
"Christopher Robin told me what it said, and then I could."
"Well, I'll tell you what this says, and then you'll be able to."

div.p: So Owl wrote ... and this is what he wrote:
HIPY PAPY BTHUTHDTH THUTHDA BTHUTHDY.
Pooh looked on admiringly.
said Owl carelessly.
said Pooh, very much impressed by it.

quote.s: "Well, actually, of course, I'm saying 'A Very Happy Birthday with\nlove from Pooh.' Naturally it takes a good deal of pencil to say a long\nthing like that."

div.p: said Pooh.

While all this was happening, Piglet had gone back to his own house to get Eeyore's balloon. He held it very tightly against himself, so that it shouldn't blow away, and he ran as fast as he could so as to get to Eeyore before Pooh did; for he thought that he would like to be the first one to give a present, just as if he had thought of it without being told by anybody. And running along, and thinking how pleased Eeyore would be, he didn't look where he was going ... and suddenly he put his foot in a rabbit hole, and fell down flat on his face.

Piglet lay there, wondering what had happened. At first he thought that the whole world had blown up; and then he thought that perhaps only the Forest part of it had; and then he thought that perhaps only _he_ had, and he was now alone in the moon or somewhere, and would never see Christopher Robin or Pooh or Eeyore again. And then he thought,

quote.s: "I wonder what that bang was. I\ncouldn't have made such a noise just falling down. And where's my\nballoon? And what's that small piece of damp rag doing?"

div.p: It was the balloon!

quote.s: "Oh, dear, oh, dearie, dearie, dear! Well, it's\ntoo late now. I can't go back, and I haven't another balloon, and\nperhaps Eeyore doesn't like balloons so very much."

div.p: So he trotted on, rather sadly now, and down he came to the side of the stream where Eeyore was, and called out to him.
shouted Piglet.
said Eeyore.
he said.
said Piglet, having now got closer.
Eeyore stopped looking at himself in the stream, and turned to stare at Piglet.
he said.
Balancing on three legs, he began to bring his fourth leg very cautiously up to his ear.

quote.s: "It's quite easy. It's so as I can hear\nbetter.... There, that's done it! Now then, what were you saying?"

div.p: He pushed his ear forward with his hoof.
said Piglet again.

quote.s: "Yes, Eeyore, and I've brought you a present."

div.p: Eeyore took down his right hoof from his right ear, turned round, and with great difficulty put up his left hoof.
said Piglet very loudly.

quote.s: "Me going on having a real birthday?"
"Yes, Eeyore, and I brought you a balloon."
"You did say balloon? One of those big\ncoloured things you blow up? Gaiety, song-and-dance, here we are and\nthere we are?"
"Yes, but I'm afraid--I'm very sorry, Eeyore--but when I was running\nalong to bring it you, I fell down."
"Dear, dear, how unlucky! You ran too fast, I expect. You didn't hurt\nyourself, Little Piglet?"
"No, but I--I--oh, Eeyore, I burst the balloon!"

div.p: There was a very long silence.
said Eeyore at last.
Piglet nodded.

quote.s: "Here it is. With--with\nmany happy returns of the day."

div.p: And he gave Eeyore the small piece of damp rag.
said Eeyore, a little surprised.
Piglet nodded.
Piglet nodded again.
said Eeyore.

quote.s: "but what colour was this balloon when it--when it was a balloon?"

div.p: Piglet felt very miserable, and didn't know what to say. He was still opening his mouth to begin something, and then deciding that it wasn't any good saying _that_, when he heard a shout from the other side of the river, and there was Pooh.
called out Pooh, forgetting that he had said it already.
said Eeyore.
Pooh had now splashed across the stream to Eeyore, and Piglet was sitting a little way off, his head in his paws, snuffling to himself.

quote.s: "Here it is. And it's got 'A Very Happy\nBirthday with love from Pooh' written on it. That's what all that\nwriting is. And it's for putting things in. There!"

div.p: When Eeyore saw the pot, he became quite excited.

quote.s: "I believe my Balloon will just go into that Pot!"
"Balloons are much too big to go into Pots.\nWhat you do with a balloon is, you hold the ballon----"

div.p: And as Piglet looked sorrowfully round, Eeyore picked the balloon up with his teeth, and placed it carefully in the pot; picked it out and put it on the ground; and then picked it up again and put it carefully back.

quote.s: "It goes in and out like anything."
"that I thought of giving you a\nUseful Pot to put things in."
"that I thought of giving you\nSomething to put in a Useful Pot."

div.p: But Eeyore wasn't listening. He was taking the balloon out, and putting it back again, as happy as could be....
asked Christopher Robin sadly.

quote.s: "I gave him a box of paints to paint things with."
"Why didn't I give it to him in the morning?"
"You were so busy getting his party ready for him. He had a cake with\nicing on the top, and three candles, and his name in pink sugar,\nand----"

div.p: said Christopher Robin.
div.head: CHAPTER VII
IN WHICH KANGA AND BABY ROO COME
div.p: TO THE FOREST, AND PIGLET HAS A BATH
Nobody seemed to know where they came from, but there they were in the Forest: Kanga and Baby Roo. When Pooh asked Christopher Robin,
Christopher Robin said,

quote.s: "In the Usual Way, if you know\nwhat I mean, Pooh,"

div.p: and Pooh, who didn't, said
Then he nodded his head twice and said,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he nodded his head twice and said

div.p: Then he went to call upon his friend Piglet to see what _he_ thought about it. And at Piglet's house he found Rabbit. So they all talked about it together.

quote.s: "Here are we--you,\nPooh, and you, Piglet, and Me--and suddenly----"

div.p: said Pooh.
said Pooh.

quote.s: "And Owl--and then all of a sudden----"

"all--of--us,
and then, suddenly, we wake up one morning and, what do we find? We find
a Strange Animal among us. An animal of whom we have never even heard
before! An animal who carries her family about with her in her pocket!
Suppose I carried my family about with me in my pocket, how many
pockets should I want?"

div.p: said Piglet.

quote.s: "And one more for a\nhandkerchief--that's eighteen. Eighteen pockets in one suit! I haven't\ntime."

div.p: There was a long and thoughtful silence ... and then Pooh, who had been frowning very hard for some minutes, said:

"I was talking

Animals. In which case 'Aha!' is perhaps a foolish thing to say."

div.p: Piglet was so excited at the idea of being Useful, that he forgot to be frightened any more, and when Rabbit went on to say that Kangas were only Fierce during the winter months, being at other times of an Affectionate Disposition, he could hardly sit still, he was so eager to begin being useful at once.

div.p: said Rabbit when he had finished writing, and Pooh and Piglet sat listening very eagerly with their mouths open. This was what Rabbit read out:
div.head: PLAN TO CAPTURE BABY ROO
div.p: 1. _General Remarks._ Kanga runs faster than any of Us, even Me.
2. _More General Remarks._ Kanga never takes her eye off Baby Roo, except when he's safely buttoned up in her pocket.
3. _Therefore._ If we are to capture Baby Roo, we must get a Long Start, because Kanga runs faster than any of Us, even Me. (_See_ 1.)
4. _A Thought._ If Roo had jumped out of Kanga's pocket and Piglet had jumped in, Kanga wouldn't know the difference, because Piglet is a Very Small Animal.
5. Like Roo.
6. But Kanga would have to be looking the other way first, so as not to see Piglet jumping in.
7. See 2.
8. _Another Thought._ But if Pooh was talking to her very excitedly, she _might_ look the other way for a moment.
9. And then I could run away with Roo.
10. Quickly.
11. _And Kanga wouldn't discover the difference until Afterwards._

Well, Rabbit read this out proudly, and for a little while after he had read it nobody said anything. And then Piglet, who had been opening and shutting his mouth without making any noise, managed to say very huskily:

quote.s:
"LINES WRITTEN BY A BEAR OF VERY LITTLE BRAIN

 On Monday, when the sun is hot
 I wonder to myself a lot:
 "Now is it true, or is it not,"
 "That what is which and which is what?"

 On Tuesday, when it hails and snows,
 The feeling on me grows and grows
 That hardly anybody knows
 If those are these or these are those.

 On Wednesday, when the sky is blue,
 And I have nothing else to do,
 I sometimes wonder if it's true
 That who is what and what is who.

 On Thursday, when it starts to freeze
 And hoar-frost twinkles on the trees,
 How very readily one sees
 That these are whose--but whose are these?

 On Friday---"

Of course as soon as Kanga unbuttoned her pocket, she saw what had happened. Just for a moment, she thought she was frightened, and then she knew she wasn't; for she felt quite sure that Christopher Robin would never let any harm happen to Roo. So she said to herself,

div.p: Piglet began to say that this was because he had just had a bath, and then he thought that perhaps he wouldn't say that, and as he opened his mouth to say something else, Kanga slipped the medicine spoon in, and then patted him on the back and told him that it was really quite a nice taste when you got used to it.

And just when it was decided, Henry Pootel wriggled out of Kanga's arms and jumped to the ground. To his great joy Christopher Robin had left the door open. Never had Henry Pootel Piglet run so fast as he ran then, and he didn't stop running until he had got quite close to his house. But when he was a hundred yards away he stopped running, and rolled the rest of the way home, so as to get his own nice comfortable colour again....

So Kanga and Roo stayed in the Forest. And every Tuesday Roo spent the day with his great friend Rabbit, and every Tuesday Kanga spent the day with her great friend Pooh, teaching him to jump, and every Tuesday Piglet spent the day with his great friend Christopher Robin. So they were all happy again.
div.head: CHAPTER VIII
IN WHICH CHRISTOPHER ROBIN LEADS
AN EXPOTITION TO THE NORTH POLE
div.p: One fine day Pooh had stumped up to the top of the Forest to see if his friend Christopher Robin was interested in Bears at all. At breakfast that morning (a simple meal of marmalade spread lightly over a honeycomb or two) he had suddenly thought of a new song. It began like this:

quote.s: "Sing Ho! for the life of a Bear."

div.p: When he had got as far as this, he scratched his head, and thought to himself

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he scratched his head and thought to himself
quote.s: "That's a very good start for a song, but what about the second\nline?"

div.p: He tried singing
two or three times, but it didn't seem to help.

quote.s: "if I sang Hi for the\nlife of a Bear."

div.p: So he sang it ... but it wasn't.

quote.s:
"I shall sing that first line twice, and perhaps if I sing it
very quickly, I shall find myself singing the third and fourth lines
before I have time to think of them, and that will be a Good Song. Now
then:"

"Sing Ho! for the life of a Bear!
 Sing Ho! for the life of a Bear!
 I don't much mind if it rains or snows,
 'Cos I've got a lot of honey on my nice new nose,
 I don't much care if it snows or thaws,
 'Cos I've got a lot of honey on my nice clean paws!
 Sing Ho! for a Bear!
 Sing Ho! for a Pooh!
 And I'll have a little something in an hour or two!"

div.p: He was so pleased with this song that he sang it all the way to the top of the Forest,

quote.s: "it\nwill be time for the little something, and then the last line won't be\ntrue."

div.p: So he turned it into a hum instead.

Christopher Robin was sitting outside his door, putting on his Big Boots. As soon as he saw the Big Boots, Pooh knew that an Adventure was going to happen, and he brushed the honey off his nose with the back of his paw, and spruced himself up as well as he could, so as to look Ready for Anything.

div.p: He left Rabbit and hurried down to Piglet's house. The Piglet was sitting on the ground at the door of his house blowing happily at a dandelion, and wondering whether it would be this year, next year, sometime or never. He had just discovered that it would be never, and was trying to remember what "_it_" was, and hoping it wasn't anything nice, when Pooh came up.

quote.s: "we're going on an Expotition, all of\nus, with things to eat. To discover something."

div.p: In a little while they were all ready at the top of the Forest, and the Expotition started. First came Christopher Robin and Rabbit, then Piglet and Pooh; then Kanga, with Roo in her pocket, and Owl; then Eeyore; and, at the end, in a long line, all Rabbit's friends-and-relations.

quote.s: "They just came. They\nalways do. They can march at the end, after Eeyore."

little rest, I have to brush away half a dozen of Rabbit's smaller
friends-and-relations first, then this isn't an Expo--whatever it
is--at all, it's simply a Confused Noise. That's what I say."
"I'm just telling everybody. We\ncan look for the North Pole, or we can play 'Here we go gathering Nuts\nand May' with the end part of an ant's nest. It's all the same to me."

div.p: they said hastily to each other all down the line, until it got to the last one of all. And the last and smallest friend-and-relation was so upset to find that the whole Expotition was saying "Hush!" to _him_, that he buried himself head downwards in a crack in the ground, and stayed there for two days until the danger was over, and then went home in a great hurry, and lived quietly with his Aunt ever-afterwards. His name was Alexander Beetle.
